concepts.name: TCP Basics
concepts.description: Transmission Control Protocol fundamentals — what it provides (reliable, ordered, error-checked delivery) and where it sits in the network stack.

concepts.name: TCP Handshake
concepts.description: The three-way handshake (SYN, SYN-ACK, ACK) that establishes a TCP connection. Why three steps are necessary.

concepts.name: Sequence Numbers
concepts.description: How TCP uses sequence numbers to track bytes in a stream, enable ordering, and detect missing segments.

concepts.name: Acknowledgments
concepts.description: How TCP receivers confirm receipt of data. Cumulative ACKs, duplicate ACKs, and their role in reliability.

concepts.name: Retransmission
concepts.description: How TCP detects and recovers from lost segments. Timeout-based retransmission and fast retransmit via duplicate ACKs.

concepts.name: Flow Control
concepts.description: Receiver-side flow control via the sliding window. How the receiver advertises capacity and the sender adapts.

concepts.name: Congestion Control
concepts.description: Network-side congestion management. Slow start, congestion avoidance, fast recovery. How TCP infers network capacity.

concepts.name: TCP Timers
concepts.description: Retransmission timeout (RTO) calculation, keepalive timers, TIME_WAIT state. How TCP manages time-dependent behaviors.

concepts.name: DNS Resolution
concepts.description: How domain names resolve to IP addresses. The recursive query process from stub resolver to authoritative server.

concepts.name: DNS Hierarchy
concepts.description: The hierarchical namespace structure — root servers, TLD servers, authoritative servers. Delegation and zones.

concepts.name: DNS Caching
concepts.description: TTL-based caching at resolvers and clients. Cache invalidation, stale records, and negative caching.

concepts.name: DNS Record Types
concepts.description: A, AAAA, CNAME, MX, NS, TXT, SOA records. What each type stores and when it's used.

concepts.name: HTTP Request/Response
concepts.description: The request-response model. How a client sends a request (method, URI, headers, body) and receives a structured response.

concepts.name: HTTP Methods
concepts.description: GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, PATCH, HEAD, OPTIONS. Semantics, idempotency, and safety properties.

concepts.name: HTTP Status Codes
concepts.description: The five classes (1xx-5xx). Key codes and their semantics — 200, 301, 304, 400, 401, 403, 404, 500, 503.

concepts.name: HTTP Headers
concepts.description: Request and response headers. Content negotiation, caching directives, authentication, CORS. How headers control behavior.

concepts.name: TLS Basics
concepts.description: What TLS provides — confidentiality, integrity, authentication. Where it sits in the stack and why it matters.

concepts.name: TLS Handshake
concepts.description: The TLS handshake process. Key exchange, cipher suite negotiation, certificate verification. TLS 1.2 vs 1.3 differences.

concepts.name: TLS Certificates
concepts.description: X.509 certificates, certificate chains, root CAs, certificate validation. How trust is established.
